results.title: Foolish wives
results.creator_credit: Erich Von Stroheim and Universal Productions
results.brief_description: Posing as a Russian count, Stroheim preys on women; regardless of social class or status. Set in Monte Carlo, the subject matter was considered “repulsive and continental.” Stroheim, bewitching in his monacle is a satanic seducer intent on possessing the wife of an American diplomat from under his nose. The wife is more than obviously attracted to the Count’s fatal charm. “Foolish wives” was an expensive production in its day, and the excellence of the sets and costumes, along with Stroheim’s masterly direction make it a cinema classic.

results.title: Footlight parade
results.creator_credit: Lloyd Bacon, Robert Lord and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Set against the backdrop of Hollywood in the 1930’s, James Cagney stars as a Broadway musical comedy producer/director who finds himself without a job due to the arrival of talkies. He devises an inventive way of keeping the loan sharks at bay, by creating prologues that can precede the talkies themselves, riding on the coat tails of the very thing that put him out of business in the first place. The comedy and drama of the film is derived from the activities of the players who are part of Cagney’s troupe producing the prologues. There’s the gold digger (Claire Dodd), the disgruntled ex-wife (Renee Whitney), the secretary with secret artistic abilities (Ruby Keeler), the faithful Girl Friday (Joan Blondell) who stands by the man who doesn’t know that she loves him, the long suffering personal assistant (Hugh Herbert), and the young protegee (Dick Powell). Numbers created and staged by Busby Berkeley and include hits such as “Honeymoon hotel”, “Shanghai Lil” and “By a waterfall”. This was the third of Warner’s backstage musicals released in 1933, the other two being “42nd Street” and “The Gold diggers of 1933”.

results.title: Fool for love
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman, Yoram Globus, Menahem Golan and Cannon Group
results.brief_description: Robert Altman (The Player, McCabe and Mrs Miller, Nashville, Gosford Park) adapts Sam Shepard’s one room play with mixed results. Shepard plays Eddie, a handsome cowboy drifter who arrives in a depressing New Mexico roadside motel, lugging a trailer and horses. The aim of Eddie’s visit is to be re-united with the voluptuous May, a barmaid at this barren pit stop’s hotel. For her part May is being wooed by another man but is inextricably drawn to Eddie, despite the proven destructive nature of their union. Over the course of the evening she and Eddie argue violently and make up passionately as the heart-rending history of their relationship, replete with flashbacks, unfurls. Harry Dean Stanton plays a barfly whose identity holds a key role to these lovers’ sorrow. “Fool for love” garnered mostly negative reviews and found a very limited audience, regardless of praise for Basinger’s bravura performance. Most decried the device of opening up the play, outside of its claustrophobic one room structure, in favour of a wider locale, which may have robbed it of the intimate tensions generated by the ill-matched pair battling it out in a confined space. But despite this the incendiary relationship between the principal characters is astutely portrayed, achieving a suitably tragic tone within a desolate setting.

results.title: Food or famine
results.creator_credit: Alvin Bailey, Martha Varley, Stuart Legg and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: One-half of the human population is either underfed or malnourished; every year 50 million mouths are added to the world’s population, yet only one-tenth of the earth’s surface is farmed. Food production must be increased by using improved strains of crops, chemicals, land reclamation and better methods of fishing, plus research into hydroponics - growing crops in water with the necessary chemicals added which are present naturally in the soil.

results.title: On nature's trail
results.creator_credit: Jason Rosenfield and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Four young nature enthusiasts meet each Saturday morning in their local park where they let their imagination roam free, while learning many principles of ecology as they relate to everyday life. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students.

results.title: Outsiders within
results.creator_credit: Gordon Brick and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Focus”.
Examines the plight of illegal immigrants awaiting deportation at Villawood Detention Centre, New South Wales. Outlines the allegations of denial of basic human rights presented at a Human Rights Commission inquire into the Centre’s operations. Presents the views of Stuard West, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and Peter Bailey, the Human Rights Commissioner, concerning the treatment of illegal immigrants. Al Grassby, former Commissioner for Community Relations, also speaks out on human rights.

results.title: A Shame like Alice. Parts. 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Leonard Lee, SBS-TV and Lee Gordon Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Focus”.
The plight of Australia’s Aborigines around Alice Springs. Are Aborigines being treated in accordance with the United Nations Charter which states all human beings should be free and equal? Includes interviews with Neville Bonner and Al Grassby

results.title: Food Victoria: a whole world of food (MAC & PC)
results.creator_credit: Multimedia Victoria, Victorian Dairy Industry Authority and Food Victoria
results.brief_description: Victoria produces a third of Australia’s raw and processed food. The multimedia interactive program is divided into four sections: Victoria, Dairy, Stone Fruit and a Directory based on a supermarket interface. A wealth of information with excellent graphics and video presentations.
